Speaking of theory. The reason why many people in very warm climates still drink coffee and tea even during hot summers is because it makes you sweat. Which sounds bad unless there's a good breeze going then that sweat will quickly evaporate and you get to enjoy a little thing called adiabatic cooling. Which is why you sweat in the first place, it's to cool your body down so drinking something hot on a hot day can actually be cooling, just make sure you drink enough so you don't get dehydrated.

ok no i got annoyed so here is my basic tutorial on how to make tea, from a british:  1)get yorkshire tea bags. must be yorkshire 2) boil water in kettle 3)put tea bag in mug then boiled water on top (doesnt matter how much) 4) put in milk (only a sploosh) then take out the tea bag and squeeze it. You squeeze it after since it has not been in the cup long  5) Optional- Add Sugar/ sweetner  this is the only way i drink tea (unless im having a day where my body decides it doesnt like milk, in which case just take out the milk step)

Let me introduce you to Indian Chai.  Put a pan on the stove with some water, add a tea spoon of tea leaves (tea bags exist here but nobody uses them), add your sugar, ginger, lemon grass (optional), and cardamom (people add other herbs as well but this is how I like my tea). Bring the water to a boil and then add milk. Let the concoction boil. Once is boils turn down the flames and let it simmer for about 10 minutes. The more you cook the better the tea but don't overdo it or it'll turn bitter. And here you have Chai which tastes way better in a steel glass. Cheers.

The microwave is a great option for those who do not have dedicated water boiling devices, or would use a kettle/pot on a gas stove, because it is more efficient to heat just the water. And electricity is ~0.6-2x as efficient as gas, depending on supply mix.
Most people brew it like that now anyway. The amount of tea in a bag has to be higher to account for different cup sizes. The milk added before lowers the brewing temperature, so you will taste less bitter notes, but it may curdle the milk, especially straight from the kettle (just boiled).
If you add the milk first, and more milk, it will cool it, brew it less, and taste less of tea also. Partial loose leaf tea is better quality than most bag tea. The companies making different shaped bags probably buy higher quality tea. Also you normally don't open tea bags, especially because of the fine particle size, which is hard to filter out. Also you put the bag first because it "brews it better" (you get more agitation when pouring water.

All of you have left out the most important factor, the water. My brother worked in a Victorian British tea room, and they did it the traditional way from generations ago and its F**king amazing to drink. It starts with the water, You cannot use pre boiled water (or a kettle topped up, tip it out fully fresh pot), this is extremely important. Fresh oxygenated water, boiled and poured into a pre heated teapot (you don't want the water to cool at all) with tea leaves NO TEA BAGS. Keep the pot warm to keep the heat constant (longer the stronger this is personal preference.) Pour in cup, then if you have sugar add that while hot to properly mix in then at milk to taste if you want it. This was how tea was done back then, once you have tea like this you can taste the difference but people make the biggest mistake at the beginning by not using fresh water. It will make you a tea snob lol

the milk first original british method was done when there were no tea bags or mesh nets to brew in the cup. therefore, all tea was brewed in a teapot. the principle is still the same - tea is steeped in water first and the milk is added last.   when you have a teabag or mesh net, you steep the tea in the mug so the milk must be poured in last. when you steep the tea in a teapot the last thing to be added is still the milk, whether you're pouring the steeped tea onto milk already in the cup or your pour in the tea and then add milk on top.  that sour taste comes from overheating the milk and the steeping of tea doesn't work well either because the temperature of the water is too low. that's why you steep tea without milk.  it's never been a british tradition to steep tea in milk. only weirdos without tastebuds do it ğŸ˜‚

The studentâ€™s T test, which is the gold standard statistical test for significant differences, is called the T test because a mathematician named Student got into an argument with a lady who said that milk first or tea first made a difference. He did a blind test and she could tell every single tea what came first. However, he needed to know that this wasnâ€™t by chance, so he developed the Studentâ€™s â€œteaâ€ test to determine the probability she got every answer right by pure chance.

Overall a nice video! :) But I was surprised you didn't test the tea leaf "geometry". In tea bags the leaves are in smaller pieces compared to loose leaf tea which often (?) has larger leaves, or leaf pieces, which,  in theory, would affect the flavour; you even comment on the brew time difference. So in this test the "tea container" variable is not fully separated from the leaf variable. Ideally you would also test brewing the flat and pyramid bag leaves in a bauble for the same brew time. (Ideally you would also try loose leaves in the other tea containers, but that could get cumbersome.)  I think I've heard at some point (although I forgot where and with a quick search I haven't found a source) that smaller leaf pieces can tend to generate a bitter taste in the tea due to more chlorophyll being able to "leak" from the larger "cut" area.   As of yet I don't think I have seen this tested and the result would be interesting!

The British were already pouring the milk over their tea. It was the poor working class that poured the milk in their cheap cups first to stop it from chipping/cracking. The upper classes in society, with their more expensive china, actually added the milk on top.

Missed checking the correct temperature at which to steep the tea. It's important - as the different chemicals that make up the flavour and aroma of tea (there are 7-800 of them) are released differently, depending on temperature (and steeping time - which they did look at). The higher the temperature (and the longer the steeping time) the more likely you are to get the bitter tasting tannins. Rather than using boiling water, you should use water at 90-95oC.

This might seem like a hot take but boiling your water in the microwave is perfectly fine.  It might feel wrong, but there is no difference between microwave-boiled water and kettle-boiled water _except efficiency._  Boiling the water in the microwave is actually very energy efficient, it uses nearly half the energy of boiling the same amount water in a kettle on the stove and nearly a quarter compared to some gas stovetops.

Growing up, my parents would only make tea when we were sick with a cold or flu. They'd make Mormon tea (aka Brigham tea or Navajo tea) by putting some of the sticks in a pot of water (the plant has no leaves; look up images for "Mormon tea plant" if you are curious) and then would boil them in the water. Once the water turned a darker color, they'd put some of the tea in a cup (filtering out the sticks of course) and put honey in it. That drink is a miracle worker for colds and flus. Since you can't buy it in stores, we've had to harvest it ourselves. After I moved out, I couldn't go harvest it myself so I turned to elderberry and hibiscus tea to help boost my immune system. I made it almost the same way my parents made Mormon tea growing up, except I'd boil water in an electric kettle then pour that into my cup with the tea bag in it. I just made it this scientifically determined best way. I never saw myself as a tea person, but now I think I'm addicted.

Common methods of heating are as follows. Microwave (definitely the worst) stove-top kettle electric kettle internally heated hot-water dispenser  Honestly, the electric kettle and the hot-water dispenser taste about the same to me, which is probably because they use identical heating methods. Microwave Stove-top and Electric coil heating  (My personal opinion is that electric is the best.)

I currently live in Sri Lanka. We are known for having the best tea. I prefer high grown tea from Nuwara Eliya. To me adding milk and sugar dulls the flavor of the tea. I would recommend that you get a hold of tea from here. It may be labeled as â€œCeylonâ€ tea. There are many levels of tea. The Orange Pekoe label has nothing to do with the flavor. OP is generally the best outside of Gold Tips and Silver tips. This is a full leaf tea. The next level is Broken Orange Pekoe which is larger pieces of leaf. Broken Orange Pekoe Fannings  is smaller pieces with Tea Dust being the smallest pieces. As the pieces get smaller the tea will get stronger. In Sri Lanka tea with milk and sugar is called Kiri Te or Milk Tea. Nikong Te is plain tea with nothing added. Tea like wine will have different flavors based on the ground, amount of sunlight, altitude, etc. Teas from different parts of the island have different notes to it.

I might have an idea for why the milk-before-tea method produces a worse flavor. Because the tea is hot, it's essentially cooking/curdling the milk, thus making it more sour. By pouring the milk in after, it's similar to tempering the tea to even out the temperature between the two liquids and thus allowing it to better blend together without spoiling the flavor.

Good sirs I have taken it upon myself to attempt your tea recipe. Unto which I may lay my judgements. While I followed your instructions to a "Tea", if you would pardon my joke, I found myself in a quandary. Had I prepared this wrong? The lack of flavor, so uncharacteristic to what I associate tea to have, left me outright flabbergasted. Of course being a man who enjoyed sugars and the like I gave it the benefit of the doubt. I included some honey under the assumption that this would be permitable by your great council of tea aficionados. But this action only further left me in a stupor as it seemed even the overpowering sweetness of honey was dulled to an unrecognizable degree. And upon my tongue this dull flavor appeared to have washed away all semblances of my original cadence. Instead replaced by the overtly proper speech you are beholding for yourself. It appears that your tea not only removes all the joys of your sense of taste but also the joy of life as I know it. An incomparable amount of sugar, spices, and other such rich flavors will be required to compensate for this damage and restore my facilities. In conclusion your tea, while impressive in its own right and certainly a pinnacle of your culinary explorations, is simply unfit for consumption by any member of the human race that values the depth and richness that life provides with all of its wondrous palatable splendors. Even to this moment its life sucking flavor is firmly affixed to my mouth and I fear this empty feeling may very well be incurable.

So a theory on the milk order thing.  As you're pouring the tea from the kettle first, its aerated a bit and thus cooled slightly between the moment you're pouring the tea vs the time you're pouring the milk. Not much of a temperature difference, i know, but it's probably enough. Adding the milk first means that hot tea is coming in contact with the tea at its hottest moment so that is scalds just a bit more, while also adding much more air.   Basically adding milk first means aerated and slightly scalded milk mixing with hot tea.   Adding tea first means aerated and slightly cooled tea mixing with much less scalded milk.   It'd be interesting to test.  Tbh though, I'm usually a no milk in tea kind of guy.

I think I know why the milk first tea isn't as good, why it tastes sorta "sour".  The same effect that we see in rapidly cooking egg, scrambling, is true in this setting. The boiling water rapidly heats the milk, causing it to begin to spoil. On the other hand, adding it last exposes it to the heat more slowly and prevents the spoiled flavor. That's why adding it second makes it noticeably smoother and richer- you're not cooking the milk (as rapidly). ğŸ’–ğŸ’– But that's just a theory, a food theory. Bone apple tea

I was very apprehensive about using milk in my tea, but always felt like my plain tea with sugar was too light, if that makes sense. Make turkish tea my guy.  Turkish Tea:   Get a Caydanlik (a smaller pot nestled on top of a larger pot. The lower and larger pot is where to boil the water, while the upper pot is where to put the loose tea leaves in water), Boil water, Fill 50% of cup with boiling water, fill 20% with the liquid in the upper pot (make sure to get fragments of tea leaves in the cup), stir a lot, either add 2 cubes or sugar or honey using a wooden spoon.

The orientation of the seed mattered on the one I got to sprout, because the seed was already split naturally when I sliced my fruit open to eat it. I knew on looking at it that it was 'the one', though I'd tried a couple different times before just to experiment on the potential. The seed that grew my little sapling had no other distinctive qualities to it in addition to the small opening and the not so scientific "feeling", but they take a long while, and _will_ split (in my seed's case, split even wider) when shooting their roots from this little 'nucleus' looking thing that isn't visible before splitting. I typically would maintain the water just above 3/4s of the total height of the seed which, when it finally sprouted roots, did so around that level. This is quite interesting and funny to me as a Canadian. My families method was this:  - boil water - splash a little bit of boiling water into the teapot and splash it around - insert teabag of choice (pyramid tea bags weren't really a thing in our area) - fill tea pot with boiling water keeping a small amount in the kettle. - when tea is read pour remaining hot water into mug and splash it around before dumping it out -pour tea - add sweatener if desired - add splash of milk and enjoy tea  We were always told that warming the ceramics first was key as then their tea wouldn't get temperature shock and it was better at dissolving sweeteners. Loved the video as always but there's one big variable in the mug test that I wanted to mention.  This is not me trying to say the team messed up or anything, a lot goes into these videos and the variable I'm talking about is only an issue because mat was trying to make the amount of water in each mug being the same.  The variable is heat transfer. Normally speaking this variable wouldn't play a part in the test but because  the glass mug was used to transfer water into the other mugs, the water has had the chance to  transfer heat to the room temp glass mug  before being transferred to another room temp mug and therefore will cool the water further. By the time the glass mug gets its pour its been pre heated by the previous two mugs worth of water and so the heat transfer wont be as great.  This means that we cannot conclusively determine if glass really would or would not  keep the hottest cup of tea solely based on this video's test.

The tea bag shape probably does make a difference, but you should also be aware that the tea in most teabags is basically dregs and scraps.  If you look at loose tea (and the tea in those pyramidal teabags), it is in much bigger pieces and is not mostly semi-dust like paper teabag tea.  This might vary by brand to some degree, but looseleaf tea will generally be much better quality.  Also, I'm Canadian (= British tea tradition) and it used to be normal for me to drink about 8 cups of tea a day, from one very large teapot.  I've cut back now to about 6. You did miss one HUGE variable. Water quality. Case in point: A cup of tea in my hometown of Hull in East Yorkshire and a cup of tea in Guildford in Surrey will taste very different if the water comes directly from the tap, due to variations in the hardness, mineral content and general 'quality' of the water.  HOWEVER, put that water in a good quality filter (I use a Berkey) and the tea will taste practically identical (although not entirely as (most) filters don't do much about hardness and softness and it doesn't take much of a variation to to make a difference - Soft water is better btw)

I think milk first is traditional only for high tea / fancy tea. Traditional mug of English Breakfast tea in Britain is teabag>just boiled water from kettle>teabag out>milk. When I've gone out for an afternoon tea though, my parents put milk in the fancy teacup first then pour from the teapot. I haven't gone the hang of doing it that way though as my tea is usually too milky :(  (Random point - no one does that 'pinkies out' thing in Britain. It would probably be considered rude if anything, plus we call it the little finger.)  Loose leaf or pyramid tea bags usually have recommendations for the temperature of the water and stewing time as well (although some teapots don't have a filter so the stewing time is ignored), but classic tea bags are a personal preference. Also personal preference is the type of milk - skimmed milk is usually judged harshly, semi-skimmed or whole is exceptable, and the ultimate is Jersey Cow milk (even more so for coffee).  Another factor is the regional water - in Britain we have 'soft' and 'hard' water regions. Hard water contains more minerals and has a tendency to coat our kettles in limescale. It also apparently affects the flavour and strength of the tea. If you leave a teabag to stew in hard water too long the surface water forms an unpleasant 'scum'. I used to press the teabag to get it to stew quicker and avoid this happening, but it's not good for the tea flavour. Stirring is fine though.  Wow I knew more about tea than I realised. That explains why I keep getting it as a gift ğŸ˜

Mat Pat, there's one thing you forgot to account for: the amount of time that the milk is in the tea. Milk should definitely be poured on top, but I've found that you get the best cup of tea if you add the milk in the last minute of steeping. Personally, I think that, if you add the milk after the tea has already steeped, the milk overpowers the flavor of the tea too much. But, if you add the milk as soon as the tea starts steeping, it cools the water down and it can't steep properly. But, if you add the milk in during the last minute, the milk is infused with the flavor of the tea to create a harmonious flavor but isn't in the cup long enough to prevent the hot water from getting enough flavor out of the leaves. I agree with everything else you said in the video, but you should definitely try adding milk during the steep time

Douglas Adams and Tea from Adams' The Salmon of Doubt: Hitchhiking the Galaxy One Last Time   pgs. 67-69  Tea        "One or two Americans have asked me why the English like tea so much, which never seems to them to be a very good drink. To understand, you have to make it properly. There is a very simple principle to the making of tea, and it's this - to get the proper flavor of tea, the water has to be boilING (not boilED) when it hits the tea leaves. If it's merely hot, then the tea will be insipid. That's why we English have these odd rituals, such as warming the teapot first (so as not to cause the boiling water to cool down too fast as it hits the pot). And that's why the American habit of bringing a teacup, a tea bag, and a pot of hot water to the table is merely the perfect way of making a thin, pale, watery cup of tea that nobody in their right mind would want to drink. The Americans are all mystified about why the English makes such a big thing out of tea because most Americans HAVE NEVER HAD A GOOD CUP OF TEA. That's why they don't understand. In fact, the truth of the matter is that most English people don't know how to make real tea anymore either, and most people drink cheap instant coffee instead, which is a pity, and gives Americans the impression that the English are just generally clueless about hot stimulants.      So the best advice I can give to an American arriving in England is this: Go to Marks and Spencer and buy a packet of Earl Grey tea. Go back to where you're staying and boil a kettle of water. While it is coming to the boil, open the sealed pack and sniff. Careful - you may feel a bit dizzy, but this is in fact perfectly legal. When the kettle has boiled, pour a little of it into a teapot, swirl it around, and tip it out again. Put a couple (or three, depending on the size of the pot) of tea bags into the pot. (If I was really trying to lead you into the paths of rightousness, I would tell you to use free leaves rather than bags, but let's just take this in easy stages). Bring the kettle back up to the boil, and then pour the boiling water as quickly as you can into a cup. Some people will tell you that you shouldn't have milk with Earl Grey, just a slice of lemon. Screw them. I like it with milk. If you think you will like it with milk, then it's probably best to put some milk into the bottom of the cup before you pour in the tea. If you pour milk into a cup of hot tea, you will scald the milk. If you think you will prefer it with a slice of lemon, then, well, add a slice of lemon. Drink it. After a few moments you will begin to think that the place you've come to isn't maybe quite so strange and crazy after all."

Also, one issue with the absolute LAST part of your experiment, about the temperature of the tea in the mugs, you said the glass mug was the hottest, but keep in mind you USED the glass mug to pour the rest of the mugs of boiling water. Thereby removing any cooling effect you would have gotten from the glass mug when the actual tea was made. A self proclaimed tea connoisseur weighing in -  - No microwave - we want uniformly heated up water - Milk before water (historically) - older (not great) China - cooler milk first will help not break China cups - Loose leaf tea - needs steeping for a shorter duration of time (cannot directly compare steeping times for tea bags, loose leaf etc) - More milk is needed when we are adding milk before serving when we want to brew tea for a longer time  (and longer brewing without milk = stronger, bitter tea)

Fun fact _(Meintioned my Mat, but I was so infuriated by the idea of making tea with milk)_ : Did you know milk was originally added to tea because for a pretty long time Britain had (despite being the bigest empire where sun didn't set) no access to a quality ceramic, so their cups would break when filled with hot water. Ok, I want to start by saying that I thoroughly enjoyed this episode. While I am more of a coffee drinker than a tea drinker, I do enjoy it on occasion and it is nice to know how to get the best experience when I do.  That being said.  I am going to call you on one thing. During the last portion, when you said that the glass cup holds on to the temperature longer, that might be correct, but you also used that glass mug to pour into the other two mugs. Each time you poured the water from the kettle into the glass mug, you were warming up the inside of the mug and cooling the water slightly before pouring the water into the other 2 (still cold) mugs. By the time you poured the water into it for that mug's tea, it was starting at a warmer temperature within the mug and was able to hold onto the heat longer as a result.  Still, a good video overall and all the other information was very helpful. I am planning on a trip to the UK next year, so I will wait and see how the (presumably lots) of tea I have there compares in terms of preparation. Thanks Food Theory!

You can add milk to the cup first or last if you are using a teapot. But if you are using a teabag in a cup, you cannot add milk first. The water needs to be very hot, just off boiling, to brew the tea and milk makes it too cold before it's brewed.
Love the episode and the theme you picked, but just like Steff, I'm a huge tea enthusiast myself, so in my years of tea-making, I noticed some more variables that I'd love to see tested:  1- How to heat the water? Of course not microwave, but I see some difference between slowly "heated over the fire" tea-water and fastly heated in an electric kettle (where also, the water is in contact with the metal piece that heats itself, what could influence the taste maybe making it more metallic-y  2- Whats the best tempreature? should we let the water boil like most people do or stop right before it? or even before maybe?  3- Stir the tea or let the bag soaking unmoved? I usually bounce the bag up and down, because it gets the flavour faster, but does it influence the final result?  4- Does the material of the "bag" make a difference? for example, the usual fabricky-bag vs. the metalic leaf-dipper like the one in the video or the ever more common plastic-dipper?  5- Should you dip your tea-bag in the hot water, or pour the water on top of the tea-bag (as I do sometimes because while I wait for the water to heat up I have already oppened the tea bag and rested it inside of the mug)? A Similar question would go for loose-leaves teas made in the tea-pot. Do you pour the hot water on top of the leaves? heat the water already with the leaves inside? or throw the leaves loosely on top?  Anyway, this are just some ideas of how you could try to improve your tea even more, and I know many other ideas might come since the world of tea is so fascinating haha Ah, and btw, I'm 100% on MatPat's NO MILK side of things haha, why ruin this perfect, simple drink by adding milk on it!

My one gripe with this video is the use of a tea ball for the loose-leaf tea. When loose-leaf tea is brewed, the leaves expand to 2-3 times their original size, allowing for an even extraction. A tea ball doesn't allow the tea leaves to open up correctly, leading to the weaker tasting tea in the video. If you did the same test again, but with a tea strainer that allows the tea to open up properly, the loose-leaf tea would have won easily.

The proper way to make tea: 1. Using the large paper type bag, heating water to near boiling. A drip coffee pot does this well. 2. Steep for about 7-10 minutes.  3. Fill a US Gallon container with ice, these are usually labeled for tea. 4. Put bags on the ice, if you sweeten add sugar now to the hot tea. 5. Pour tea over ice, add water if needed.  6. Squeeze tea bags. 7. Enjoy your proper tea.

You know what they say about tradition: it's just peer pressure from dead people.
Milk in first or last was one of those things a Brit could use to judge social class. Upper class could afford the thin china cups that could break from thermal shock so milk went in first. Lower class people had thick clay mugs so milk went in after.   Thankfully itâ€™s no longer important but you might still be able to guess whether a Brit has a richer or poorer background by how they make their tea.

In my experience a lot of Asian countries and most of Europe don't add milk to their tea.
I'm British and always put the milk in last. Milk is added to colour the tea to the desired colour (which indicates the strength of the tea - darker colour = stronger tea). If you put milk in first, you could over milk it and end up with a very milky Tik Tok tea, but you can always add a bit more milk in if it's not yet at the right colour.  I also don't leave it for 3 minutes - who has that time? I pour water onto the bag in the cup which I find speeds the process and then take the bag out after about 30 seconds but do squeeze the bag a bit to get more flavour out. Question for Matpat. When you tested the milk first vs on top, did you pour already brewed tea on top of the milk? I have found that when I make a pot of already brewed tea in a teapot and pour it over milk, it tastes similar to adding the milk to the top in an already brewed cup of tea. Because the tea is actually steeping in the milk, I find that the tea is creamier (similar to certain recipes for bubble tea or matcha). How i make my tea: put some water in the kettle and boil it. Put the boiled water in the cup (instead of using a kettle, you could also get it straight from the coffee machine). Put the teabag in the cup and lift it up and down a few times. This prevents you from having to wait about 3 minutes. Pull the teabag out and lay it on something to prevent you from having to clean it. Put in sugar as you'd like (no sugar is fine too, but i usually put in 1 or 2 scoops). Let it cool down a bit so you don't burn ur mouth or tongue. Stir it to evenly devide the sugar over the tea. Last step: enjoy ur tea!

In Poland we actually threat tea with milk as a completely separate drink from just normal tea: Tea without any milk is what we call tea or more precisely "herbata", tea with 5 to 15ml of milk is what we call "zabielanka", and tea with more milk than that is something that we call "bawarka"

They got it completely the wrong way around. Putting the milk in first is not the traditional way, putting the tea in first is. It was tradition to demonstrate the high quality of your porcelain by stressing it with near boiling water before adding the milk. Putting the milk into the cup first was the practical way of doing it, for those that didn't have the finest porcelain (or weren't concerned with showing off their tea set). They alluded to that in the video, even. Taste testing aside, there are also scientific studies that show that putting milk in first makes the objectively better cup of tea, and they explain why it works.  If you prefer the taste when milk is added to tea, by all means do make it that way, just know that the scientific evidence does not support your subjective experience.

Hey Matt,  Pretentious tea snob here.  Overall a fun episode and I liked watching the tea journey. however, there are two things that stood out I need to mention: 1) I saw a methodological flaw in the steeping part. your focus was on shape but not size of the steeping container even though your explanation talked about room to bloom being a factor. extra large flat teabags can provide just as much room as the pyramid for similar effects as they will bulge in the center as the tea steeps. as for the tea bauble, most of us tea snobs don't use them because they don't give enough room for the good leaves, and instead will use open basket strainers or let it steep in an open cup and strain through a pour though strainer.   2) I'm also disappointed that you didn't look into the chemistry behind the milk in first or tea in first question, because that is a fascinating subject. Adding the milk later can denature some of the proteins, leading to some purists to feel the overall mixing is compromised. The reason the tea you had was less bitter when adding the milk second was that when the milk is added second, it interacts with the tannins more, preventing them from fully expressing themselves reducing the bitterness. In teas with an unbalance bitterness profile, that can help to bring the bitterness back into balance. but if the tea already has a nice balanced bitterness profile, you can lose out (which is why there are some varieties of tea I just don't put milk in at all)  Other than those two issue, loved the episode and I can't see what you do next
With all your scientific tests, you all just took  "don't microwave your water" as fact without testing it.  Hate to break to all the Brits out there, and Steph, but microwaving your water is no different than any other method of heating it up.  The only real difference is power consumption in the heating process, and you might burn your hand on the mug if you use a microwave.   Microwaving water has zero effect on flavor and nutritional value of water.

Current personal brew - 2:1 OP tea to Rooibos. Daytime tea 10g of OP to 5g of Rooibos in 900ml of water. Steeped for 5-10 minutes held above 85c and below 95c. Just enough milk and sugar to cut the tannins and be able to tell it's sweetened. Exact amount depends on what milk is available, whether you use table sugar or honey, and your personal tannin sensitivity.  Afternoon or nighttime tea 2 grams of OP to 1 gram R per cup steeped for 3-4 minutes, same temp, significantly less milk/sugar needed per ml of tea to cut tannins and be able to tell it's sweetened.

All the parameters they say is the "best" isn't exactly true, but a good starting point, you should play around and experiment with all of them because there's a lot of variables they didn't account for, like wall thickness of the cup lowers the temp the tea actually experiences by a lesser or grater amount, how much tea to use per 100ml depends on the individual tea, where you live can impact the water hardness and there are things you can do to account for it. whether you pour directly on the bag or around it (called rim brewing) so you don't shock the tea with high temps that are slightly too high.  The thing with putting the milk in first, it was also done because it makes a better brew IF the milk is unpasteurised. they found that putting the milk in after made the protein molecules clump together, but found no difference with pasteurised milk. we don't have that issue now so after is the preferred method.

The thing with the milk is widely known and consistent with the British way. If you are brewing the tea in a mug then you put the tea in first as otherwise your scorching the milk when you add the boiling water but also your water has been cooled slightly by the milk meaning its not hot enough to fully extract the tea flavours. However if your brewing the tea in a pot (which should be warmed with a swill of boiling water first) then you add the milk to the cup first to cool the tea down to a more drinkable and enjoyable temperature

a Brit here. The milk thing is a problem when using a teabag. The water used to make tea needs to be at 100C (212F). Pouring the milk into a mug first, lowers the temperature of the water and you don't get the full flavour of the tea. Pouring the milk into the cup first when using a teapot won't make a huge difference as the tea has already brewed and the magic has happened. The 'Tradition' MatPat busted wasn't. They just made tea wrong. Redo the test with tea in a pre-warmed pot and milk poured into a teacup, not a mug. You will find it tastes the same, or slightly better as a teabag in a mug, with boiling water and add the milk last.

So fun fact, British person here. The milk going in the bottom or top has been a huge contentious point here - I've generally put it in the bottom of the cup (though no more) but there's a second part to the history you were talking about. Cheap china would crack with boiling tea getting poured in, so people would put the milk in first to regulate the temperature, but expensive china would not. So, people who had higher quality cups that wouldn't crack would put the tea in first and then add milk as per their liking as to not spoil the taste. Thus, when now we no longer have this issue, it became a point of debate over here.

My parents exclusively use a teapot. They add the milk into their mugs first, in the kitchen, and then carry the mugs through to the living room. If they added the milk after they'd need to take the milk through and have it sit at room temp until the tea is brewed, likely leaving condensation around the container, or, they'd need to dirty another container to take the milk through.  So, for the teapot method, I think adding the milk first makes most sense. It also let's them see how much milk they're adding, which is VERY important to them. Adding the milk first if you're putting the teabag into the mug is absolute madness!!

Alright, I have my theory.   Everything strives to reach thermal equilibrium, or room temperature. Milk poured first hits the room temperature mug, warming the milk, even if only slightly. Pouring in the hot tea, which goes straight from hot kettle to milk, heats up the milk more quickly than it cools the tea, and hot milk spoils.   Alternatively, hot tea poured into a room temperature mug cools down, even if only slightly. The milk coming straight from its cold jug, cools off the tea faster than it warms up, lessening the spoilage I brought up earlier. The differences aren't dramatic, they're subtle. The theorists did spit the "milk first" tea out because it had curdled or anything like that, it was a subtle difference that turned out to be decisive. Perhaps the slight differences in what heats up and what cools down are enough to make that change in taste.   At least, that's what I figured was happening, that's why I always add cold dairy last to everything. Figured Mat would explain ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

I personally think such taste tests should be done without the taste testers knowing which tea cup is prepared in what manner.  Have someone off camera/not partaking in the taste keep record of what mug corresponds to what type.   Doing it the way you do does sorta lend some issues with bias and simply placebo or confirmation bias when testing.  *Edit:* The reason I bring this up is cause a study/experiment was done with some "experience wine taste testers" and they were served a bottle of cheap wine and a bottle of expensive wine. In the first test, the testers got to see what wine was what, and they all unanimously said the more expensive wine tasted better, had richer flavor, etc.  However, for the second test they moved the more expensive wine into the cheap bottle and vise-versa, without the testers knowing. The testers still unanimously said that the wine served in the expensive bottle (what they thought was the expensive wine, but was the cheap one) was better, had richer flavor, etc.   There's a reason blind taste tests are a thing as our other senses and expectations can skew results.

In terms of the order you should add your milk there is the issue of the fact that milk begins to curdle at 82Â° while water boils at 100Â°. So if you add the milk in second it gives the water time to cool down reducing the chance of having a more sower tasting tea. Also just heating your milk too quickly can make it start to curdle even if it does not yet begin to boil.

This works with any mugs I have but try it at your own risk, my tea goes a little like this:  -Fill the mug with hot water from a kettle almost to the top. -When putting in a teabag it should raise the water level right to the brim. -After removing the teabag, refill the cup to the brim with milk. -Stir clockwise or counter clockwise fast enough to make a noticeable dip in the middle of the tea, then begin stirring the opposite direction to stop the water flowing around the mug.  This is how I have made tea for multiple decades and I have never had complaints, only a few moments of praise. My best guess for why milk first vs milk on top makes a difference is temperature. It's possible that the tea is still hot enough to cause the milk to start to curdle if you put the milk in first, where as if you put the milk in after you've poured the tea it has had a chance to cool a bit, possibly just enough to drop below the curdling point of the milk.

Also looks like you forgot about the great stirring direction debate and if/how that would effect teabags shape and steeping time!!  If you crack out a teaspoon and stir while it steeps, then you are increasing the movement of tea leaves, not only does this give flat teabags a chance, but also improves rate of osmosis and decreasing the amount of steeping time necessary. As for stirring I opt for roughly 6 fast swirls in each direction , but some people swear you only go clockwise, while others insist on counterclockwise!  Im a little surprised you didnâ€™t go into science of why water first it superior!! We all know heat increases the amount of movement in molecules, so when you combine tea and hot water it increases reaction and improved steeping. By adding refrigerated milk first, you are reducing the max temperature the tealeaves/bag will be exposed too.  Hopefully that makes sense.l.lIâ€™m rubbish at explaining this stuff lol!

my thoughts on why 'milk first' was more sour and such is because the hot water likely scalded the milk as it was poured in. pouring the milk second cools the tea and helps prevent scalding, whereas pouring the tea second quickly heated the milk and scalded/soured it. its also a matter of how fast you pour it, since when you add milk second you instinctively pour it slower so as to not overflow your mug, which in turn lets the milk and tea meet temps more smoothly and also prevents scalding the milk. When you have more room in the mug you feel free to pour it faster, therefore, again, scalding the milk because too much heat was added too quickly.  My personal method of making tea that I've always used, that happens to closely follow what the conclusion was in the video, goes as follows: Heat your water to near boiling, not a full boil or you'll blanch the leaves, and pour into your chosen mug (I use a sturdy ceramic one) with a pyramid bag if available (though I use the rectangle ones too) after approximately 3 minutes, remove the tea bag and add a hearty splash of milk (which I guesstimate is the 26 ml of milk like suggested) then, since I like my tea sweet, I add about two droppers of liquid stevia extract (which I would guess is like a quarter of a- or a third of a teaspoon of liquid stevia extract, or maybe less)

For the record, since I am not sure it was mentioned, pouring additives before or after only actually matter based on the type of drink. If you want a drink where flavor is fully distributed, you pour the main substance last so everything mixes properly. If you want more of what all of you liked, you are having a drink that is surface cooled enough to drink faster. You taste the sweeter cream flavor which then more subtly introduces the lesser sweet (or savory) flavor. Just wanted to mention that.

Your taste test on milk v tea first reached the exact opposite conclusion of the college study that came out a few years back (sorry, don't remember which college and do not want to search, Google hates me). Their findings were that adding cold milk to hot tea with all it's tannic acids  insta-curdled the milk and soured the brew where pouring hot tea into cold milk raised the temperature gradually without shocking the milk (similar to the process of coddling or tempering eggs for a sauce).

Which should be the next video by the way... is often used wrong. just slapping something in, punching in the time, and bob's your uncle, is just wrong. you need to set your power level to the correct level depending on the food or beverage you're trying to warm up. Ideal tea: - Use your coffee percolator but without coffee grounds to heat the water - Use two bags of tea per cup - Steep them for five to ten minutes - Be sure to squeeze the bag afterward to get all those delicious tannins in there - Add one or two ice cubes to your first cup or several to chill it to ideal drinking temperature. -- PROTIP: You can pour tea into an ice cube tray and freeze it to make sure future tea has tea flavored ice available, so you can chill it without watering it down - Don't add dairy, that's gross! Milk or cream is for coffee, not for tea or hot cocoa!  I drink a pot of tea once every couple months, usually if I _really_ want a drink of something more flavorful than water but can't handle the amount of caffeine in an additional pot of coffee over my norm (such as if it's late at night).  Ideal coffee: - Buy the cheap bulk coffee grounds, like ones with the brand name/iconography of the store you're buying from rather than the likes of Folgers or anything fancy or that has its own restaurant - Use half as many grounds as directed - Add whole milk, half and half, or heavy whipping cream to taste - You might want to add an ice cube or three to your first few cups of a pot, but like tea you can pour coffee into ice cube trays and freeze it to cool down coffee with  I drink one to three pots of coffee this way every single day.  Ideal hot cocoa: - Fill a cup with hot water; the tap running hot is usually warm enough -- I said WATER, not MILK, you weirdo! - Add a packet of hot cocoa powder - Optionally, stir with a peppermint candy cane if you want a lot of extra sugar and a little tiny bit of extra flavor. Mint chocolate isn't for everyone. - Don't drink more than one of these a day; coffee and tea you can have in abundance if you don't add sugar, but hot cocoa is literally just a liquid candy.

Is tea soup? You leave plants and meat in boiling water with some spices to basically make any soup, that means if you do basically the same without meat and adding sweeteners like sugar or honey into boiling water you make tea, so basically it has to be the same because it's the same way done, you put stuff into boiling water and cook it out to make the water taste funky.  Another question:Is Smoothie stew? Smoothie is basically fruits and vegetables shredded down to a goopy drinkable substance. Stews are Also vegetables that get shredded down and cooked and served as a goopy substance. Before you say smoothie doesn't gets cooked, stews get served cold or even cooked without adding any heat, like cucumber stew that has variants to its recipe(I personally prefer to make it hot and eat it warm, even though most people prefer it cooled down idk why). Anyway, Smoothie is like the Variant of cucumber stew where you basically shred down your food, don't cook it and have your smoothie, but cucumber stew is stew. So why is smoothie smoothie and not stew? Before you say because most smoothies have fruits and vegetables while stews only have vegetables, Pumpkins are per Definition No vegetables because they have seeds, same goes for cucumbers, because they are also pumpkin plants. So this rule doesn't actually apply to stew. So smoothie is in fact cold cooked and served stew.  And now the most important question of the internet, is cereal soup?  Some soups are liquids that get cooked and then stuff gets added like Pho. Milk gets cooked to 60Â°c because bacteria needs to be killed, that's called pasteurisation and you rarely have milk packages that don't have the "pasteurized" label on them because it's (at least in my country) a requirement to do so(or write down if it isn't pasteurized, but about no market actually sells that super fresh milk) so that applies to cereal. Some soups also get served cold and added stuff to them, like Cereal. You add either your milk to the cereal like a logical thinking intelligent individual or you add your cereal to the milk, but the way you add which ingredient doesn't actually change it being soup because see how pho gets served:You take your rice noodles, vegetables and meat and then add the steaming hot broth on it to cook the ingredients, so you have to add the ingredients first to cook them. So basically cereal is soup defined by all arguments I just thought of while writing this comment. I was just about to make my cuppa and decided to check out what I was doing wrong first. Turns out not a lot, but the one place I did change things was the bag shape. I use flat bags because that is what my favourite tea comes in. So a quick hack. By pinching the sides of the flat bag and pulling them outward, I was able to create a rhomboid shape (like two square pyramids with their bottoms connected or a d8 if you Tabletop RPGs) and then used those to make my tea. I have to say, the difference was amazing. So don't despair if your bags are flat, just pull the sides out so they form a rhomboid giving the leaves plenty of room inside the bag, and then get to steeping!

I'm British and would never put the milk in first, though partly that's because I always brew my tea in the mug, and you definitely want to brew/steep the tea first before you add milk, rather than trying to brew tea in a mixture of water and milk, which is why vending machine tea is awful. Another reason for milk on top is because you should add the sugar to the hot tea before you cool it down with the milk, so that the sugar can more easily disolve through the tea, meaning you use less sugar to gain the same amount of sweetness, and you don't end up with left over sugary mush in the bottom of the cup after you have drunk your tea.

i have 2 slightly differnet ways of making tea an the method depends on if i am using bag or loose leaf, just remember when making tea a lot of it is personal preferance in strength, milk ration and sugar, so experiment till you find your preferance, a veey interestng video.  Bag-  its sugar, teabag, slow pour water, stir gently, steep for about a minute an a half, add a small amount of milk, stir gently a second time, squeeze the bags (only when using cheap bags, which happens sometimes, sadly more often these days) then drop bag in bin, tea made in about 5 minutes (including bloiling time)  loose Leaf- warm teapot with some of the boiled wate then pour down the sink, (possibly a personal quirk of mine that i picked up watching great gran and grandma making tea in a pot) a leaves in strainer(i actually use a loose leaf tea blend, not the inside of a teabag), shake gently, leave for 5minutes, add sugar to cup, add a splash of milk, gently pour tea ensuring a steady flow of liquid into the cup, gently stir, normally reserve this for when i have people over as this way takes a little more time and effort.   i do however use the loose leaf method for herbal teas (i like loose blend teas) this is normally done as a calming/comforting thing, when im stressed or sick ill often make a pot of herbal tea grab my snood, a heaty wheaty (one of those microwavle grain things, really good, my fave one is lavander infused) and hunker down on the sofa to watch something that takes little processing power as i enjoy my tea.

Brit here, and here's my tea method: Earl grey tea bags, add cinnamon, and coconut sugar (has a natural caramel flavour) Pour in the kettle water, and stir around for a moment then squeeze it out Then add a good amount of milk and stir again (MatPat commented that squeezing releases bitter tannins, but the thing that releases it most is TIME. Time steeps tannins, heat steeps caffeine. So hot and fast gives the best caffeine to tannin ratio) (Squeezing is also traditional for 2 reasons: getting every last drop literally, and makes disposal easier with a drier bag) When having tea at other's I'll ask for normal tea with 2 sugars and "way too much milk" (aka about 1/3 total is milk) Milk makes it actually drinkable temperature and dilutes the bitter flavours  I should note I'm hypersensitive to bitter flavours though, so use fast steeps and milk and sugar to help counter the natural bitterness

I'm not sure about traditional methods but pouring the milk in before the tea is seen as a high crime in the UK punishable by permanent banishment from the kitchen.......the milk ALWAYS goes in last.
I feel the top/bottom milk experiment doesn't take into account the traditional method. You start boiling the water -> stewing the tea in a teapot, then while that's happening you use that time to get the milk out and add the right amount of milk to each mug. You simply pour the tea in after that, perhaps asking if anyone takes sugar.  You want the temperature to be high when you stew the tea and the temperature to be a little more mild when you add the milk. If you add boiling water straight to milk, it may sour the milk, especially because adding water/tea to the milk will mix it faster than adding milk to the tea. Additionally, you cool the water that the tea is supposed to stew in with the cold milk which may dimimnish the tea's flavour. When you go teapot -> milk, it's essentially the same to adding milk on top except the milk should mix in faster. In both cases you combine stewed and slightly cooled tea with the milk though apparently the teapot will be even cooler than if you just did it with the mug, so in theory, the milk-bottom + teapot method should be the best.  Which is to say, the traditional method is best, not only for efficiency but for taste when serving an audience (this is very important for the UK! Drinking tea is more often a social experience than drinking coffee is). This, however, may not extend to solo tea drinking due to the fact you'll likely not use a teapot.  IN SUMMARY: The test Matt & Co. used is valid (You cannot see it, but it appears they've poured boiling water into milk instead of using a teapot which has spoiled the milk) but the conclusion that has been drawn is incorrect (they did not follow the traditional method, but said that the traditional method is wrong). I invite Matt & Co. to repeat the milk-order test with teapot stewing instead and they may even find it to be just slightly better. In any case, I appreciate the video.

The tea in the pot and the tea in the mug were the same temperature. It was the act of pouring the tea from the pot into a second vessel, a room temperature mug, that lowered the temperature of the tea. In the service industry a good waiter will preheat teacups or coffee mugs by filling them with hot water and pouring it out so the mug won't totally zap the heat of the beverage.

As a daily tea maker and drink here in the UK, you overlooked a few things.  First, don't fully boil the water, bring it to as close to boiling as you can without actually letting it boil. This is particularly true for Asian teas.  Second, putting the tea bag in the hot water or pouring the water over the teabag already in the cup. I find that tea is much smoother and stronger when you pour the water directly over the bag. My hypothesis is that when you put water in first, it cools just enough to change the reaction it has with the tea leaves.  Last, tannins are a bigger issue than mentioned in the video. Not only can they add a bitter taste, but it has a strickening effect on your taste buds that gives you a dry aftertaste.  I fully expect to see a part two where these are all addressed!

Here's the thing, as I understand, British NOBILITY, who COULD afford better higher quality china that wouldn't crack to heat shocks, and could replace them if they did, DID do tea first milk second. The queen did so every day until her death. So the British are still right about tea, it's just their peasantry hasn't yet adjusted to living like kings of old.  A similar situation is people who still put sugar and self-rising flour in cornbread even though they're using better cornmeal now. After the Civil War during Reconstruction, back when they were using Field Corn cause that's all they could afford, it needed that to not be hard and taste flat, basically adopting the recipe of former slaves. Meanwhile the rich (or stubbornly proud) families kept using Sweet Corn like they always had. So now there's a culture war in the American South about sugar in cornbread, because some people's traditional recipes are working under the assumption you're making due with animal feed.

Just my personal opinion, but: - if you add anything except for the hot water to your tea, you're not making tea, you're making a tea-based cocktail - if you don't like the taste of pure tea, this means that either you don't like tea in general or you haven't found the right leafs  - I have nothing against adding milk or sugar to my tea (but I don't call this mix a tea) - teapot is not the only good option, you can also try french press or samovar. Thus, hot water will cool down more significantly in a teapot at the biginning of the brewing, making the brewing temperature sub-optimal. If you're wondering about the milk on top vs bottom, assuming no mixing has occurred, it's most likely due to convection processes. Cool milk on top allows a current and diffusion of temperature to be created that is likely smoother than the reverse option with cooler liquid, i.e. the milk, staying at the bottom and not likely being able to react with the tea as much as milk from the top. As a British guy who consumes Steph level amounts of tea, (easily 3-4 cups a day), and since I was a kid, it was always:  1. Boil water in kettle 2. Put tea bag in mug (for making a cup for yourself) OR 2 bags in a teapot (if making enough tea for several people) 3. Once water has boiled, add to cup or teapot, depending on desired quantity.  4. Wait 3-5 minutes to steep (this depends on the kind of tea itself you're drinking as well) 5. Add a teaspoon or 2 of milk, to taste, possibly also sugar. (This again depends on the kind of tea.) 6. Enjoy.   As someone who drinks a lot of different kinds of tea, I won't always add milk or sugar. For my standard 3 cups of Earl Grey/day, I'll add a little bit of milk, but no sugar.   However, for something a little sweeter or on the fruity side, like a chamomile, or perhaps some loose leaf tea with little bits of dried fruit and such, I wouldn't add milk.   So that's maybe the other factor that could've been taken into consideration with the experiments. It also depends on the kind of tea itself you're drinking as well. Just my thoughts. :)

I'm afraid that the results in this video are skewed, and/or tampered with. First up is the steeping. I saw Steph stirring the sieve around a bit. It is slow, but could make a difference. You'll have to make new test results when the bags and sieve are just sitting there, are moved around now and again, moved around constantly, and at different speeds. Another factor to consider is dipping the bag after steeping. Straight onto the saucer without dipping, dripping or shaking? Let it drip? Shake it? Dip a couple of times before all of the above? On that note, need more combinations of water, tea and milk order (in a cup). Pour the water on the bag, or dip the bag in the water? Pour the milk on the bag then the water, or the bag on the milk then the water? At least 7 different combinations can be achieved here. Now lets talk about the cups. Not only are they of different materials but also different shapes. True, these are the things you'd find in your typical teacup store, but my mother has drunk tea out of different cups with almost the same shape and has tasted a difference. Chances are that while the material seems the same to the untrained eye it can be a difference in quality, who made them and how cheaply. Not to run up your bill, but if you want to have accurate results on whether different materials (non-porous) make the tea taste differently you'll have to have cups made in the same shape and size. As you said, the wider rim makes it cool down quicker, and sometimes can affect the taste (steeping in a more rapidly cooling water).  Now what do I know? Cinnamon & Apple, some lemon in and honey on the side when one gets a cold. And no, no milk for the lactose intolerant.

As a ceramic artist, I am weeping. Guys, please PLEASE do the material test again and actually get a decent testing sample pool. When I was in school, we were actually encouraged to do this kind of test regularly with all the cups or mug we would make. Ceramic mugs vary a lot and if you get one from an artist, they can 100% make it so that it will affect aroma and temperature a LOT. Ceramic itself has a lot of variables. Stoneware, porcelain, and red clay bodies will all have different heat retention. Thickness of the clay also varies things too. A flared out lip or a thick base will affect things heavily. A single mug does not adequately reflect the variability that is ceramic!

The only reason milk was put in to tea first was, because originally back in the days of olde, Tea was served in thin China cups and hot tea would break the bone china so cold milk was added first to soften the blow of the hot tea. Today folk drink out of mugs & paper cups etc so that milk first doesnt matter. Also back then Tea was hellishly expensive & only for the higher society types and locked in a caddy that the lady of the house would keep upon her. Bit like sugar was when that first became a thing, I mean if you look into what the first uses of sugar were it would boggle the mind. Also it was drinking tea that made people eventually realise that boiling the water killed germs as people who drank tea didn't get ill as much as those slurping rott water. Don't quite remember how this came about but it did somewhere along the chain.

As an American who occasionally drinks tea, here's my method.  Lazy Method Step 1:  Get a measuring cup (at least 1 cup) full of water Step 2: Heat at high power in the microwave for 2:30 Step 3: Pour water over the tea bag in the mug Step 4: Cover the mouth and let steep for 5 minutes Step 5: Add sweetener (two teaspoons of sugar or some honey) Step 6: Let cool for 3-5 minutes  Non-Lazy Method Step 1: Get a medium-sized stove pot and fill it with 1-2 cups of tea. Step 2: Cover and heat until boiling Step 3: Transfer water to mug and add tea bag Step 4: Cover the mug and let steep for 5 minutes Step 5: Add sweetener (two teaspoons of sugar or some honey) Step 6: Let cool for 3-5 minutes  The lazy method is quicker, but the tea is weaker tasting. The non-lazy way is slower, but the tea has a more robust flavor. Also, I only use a pot because I don't have a tea kettle.  I also don't add milk because I don't like the taste of it, and I actually prefer to use just enough sweetener that it's not bitter but not too much that it takes away from the flavor.
See, the problem is equating British with "traditional" method...

Here's a method you didn't cover. I use a French press for my loose-leaf tea. It's normally a device used for making coffee, but I find it pretty useful (just... don't use it for both coffee and tea, my French press is dedicated to tea use only). Unlike the other tea-bag methods, it lets the leaves float around in the press and steep from all angles, and as long as you're not overfilling it pressing it won't squeeze the leaves unnecessarily. Not only is this useful for normal "boiling water plus leaves" tea, I also use it for cold-brewed tea, which I've sometimes started the night before and re-heated next morning. It's a very different flavor as most of the bitter tannins don't leach into it (they dissolve at the higher temperatures), even from a lower-grade orange pekoe.  But sometimes of course I don't want to wait and just chuck a tea bag into the kettle-boiled water in the ol' pot. Sometimes simple is all you need.

I love the episode.  But my question is, did they heat up the cups and pot beforehand?  Did they use a cozy to keep the pot warm?  I drink mostly green tea, so my temperatures are lower so I can use different techniques to lower my tea's temperature while brewing, but with british more so English Breakfast, it is recommended you heat up the cup AND pot, so the heat loss from the transfer of the hot water isn't lost.  Losing that heat will result in not as fully opened tea leaves.  Usually hot water into a cold cup will result in a dramtic change in temperature 5-8C which is considered outside the range for tea.  Temperatures are important in tea!

Lemonade recipe   6 lemons 1 and 1/4 cups of sugar 5 cups of water   Tools  Mixing Bowl Cooking pot mesh strainer. Lemon/vegetable peeler. Lemon juicer (optional) Serving Pitcher  1. Wash Lemons. 2 Peel zest from 6 lemons with a veggie peeler. 3 Cover the lemon zest with a 1 and 1/4 cup of sugar in a mixing bowl leave for 2 hours but longer is better 4 Bring 5 cups of water to a boil turn off the heat and ad the lemon-sugar mixture including the peel stir and let the sugar dissolved (about five minutes) 5Strain liquid into the mixing bowl through a mesh strainer to excise the peels 6 do not add the lemon juice immediately let the liquid sit until room temperature about a half hour 7 Cut lemons in half and squeeze into the bowl through the mesh strainer  8 Pour lemonade into serving pitcher cover in cling wrap and let it refrigerate until nice and chilly (pouring the lemonade over ice without chilling it first will melt the ice and water it down so get it nice and cold.

I expected it to taste bitter when tea was added on top of milk, and to have a mixed flavor when milk was added on top of tea, both were added at the same time, or milk was added first but then stirred after the tea was added. Considering that's exactly what happened, I feel like they just didn't stir it after they poured the milk first, so the lighter, more watery (less viscous, I suppose?) tea wasn't able to break evenly into (and thus "auto-mix") the milk it was being poured into, whereas the heavier and thicker milk was able to shove the tea out of the way and auto-stir itself in the process.  TL;DR: I don't think they stirred their tea, and thus pouring milk on top tasted better, because it was auto-stirred when pouring. Pouring tea on milk will just make the top bitter and the bottom sweet if you don't mix it.

No one in Britain puts the milk in first, that's just weird.
Milk first was a southern tradition used by the lower class as people couldn't afford the correct cups, but higher class and those in northern England (usually because they made the cups) had the right cups and could put milk in last. That is why a traditional tea set has a small jug for the milk so you can ad how much you like after the water has gone in, usally just after or while steeping.

For the curious, my perfect cup of tea goes like this: Honey first, just enough to coat the bottom of the cup.  Milk next, straight from the fridge, about 1/5th the cup amount. Then the typical basic teabag, ideally I like to wedge it in the cup so it's suspended over the milk. Lastly I add the hot water, from a freshly boiled kettle, directly onto the teabag to drop it into the milk. Once filled I double dip the teabag before using a teaspoon to poke it and help the tea leaves disperse around the bag better. 3-5 minutes later (I like my tea strong enough like but yeah the whole 3 minutes thing definitely holds up) I scoop out the teabag and finally I give it all a good stir, as if I'm starting a little whirlpool at the bottom which I slowly work it upwards.   I'd legitimately be really curious if Steph and/or Tom try it and what their thoughts were.  ...*sigh* I really want a cup of tea now
Big flaws here, Matty-boy.  1. What tea are you using to test? If it's not high quality, there's going to be a mix of off-cuttings and dust in the product, and that will make your results inconsistent between different tests. They also could be sitting on a shelf for a year before you use them, and different seasons yield different qualities.  2. By limiting your analysis to the differences between American & British tea, you're only comparing arguably the two worst methods in the world. They both use a lot of water and very few leaves steeped for a relatively long time (a minute plus instead of 20-30 seconds). Usually the leaves are of lower quality for western brewing because you're not really going to get much flavor except bitterness from them that way.

I've always splashed milk in after. My view of it (my experience and opinion) pouring hot coffee or tea onto milk scalds it quick and spreads it outward from where you pour and gets hotter. Quick rise in temp for milk is not good for flavor, like putting a glass of milk in the microwave. Pouring the cold milk in after is a stream that flows and cools. Cold milk flowing behind and into the warming milk prevents it from scalding while the overall temp of the drink lowers and stabilizes. It works reverse when the goal is to cool a drink with ice. Ice first, drink has heat pulled away by the ice as it makes contact with it.

I was honestly not surprised that pouring the milk or tea first would make a difference. Any bartender will tell you that you pour the lighter drink first, then the heavier one, because it will mix better.   What was happening was that by putting the milk in first, you were pouring the lighter liquid on top, and it wasn't mixing as well, meaning the flavor would be different. May I (as a Brit) inform you of the correct way to make tea.  1. Insert the teabag (into a pot or cup depending on if itâ€™s a quick cuppa for you and a mate, or a full on formal event.)  2. Hot water poured from a freshly boiled electric kettle  3. Stir and press the teabag in the side of the cup with medium force (donâ€™t tear the bag or knock the cup over, but donâ€™t pay it and say itâ€™s a good boy either.   4. Remove teabag once it has brewed to your preferred strength, judge by colour.   4.5. If in teapot pour into cups  5. Add milk and sugar/sweetener to your taste and stir it in with the same teaspoon from earlier.   6. Remove spoon and serve.  Also brand of teabag is important. Why milk on top makes a difference: milk proteins can bond to tannic acid, forming insoluble complexes that have the umami taste of the protein and none of the astringency of tannin.  This process works better with higher heat, so when milk is added on top, more of those proteins will reach the higher tea temperature and soak up more tannic acid, as opposed to milk on bottom, where the tea is instantly cooled to milk temperature, bringing the solution up to final temp instead of down.

I'm gonna be honest with you, I think the only person, I know of, that puts the milk in first is my Nan. I think most of us have stopped the whole 'milk first' tradition ever since the rise of kettles. You can still put the milk in the cup first, but it's usually just a case of popping the kettle on, sitting in the living room while you wait for the water to boil, hearing the click when it's done, pouring it into the cup with a teabag, adding the milk then sugar (to your taste). It's just more convenient to pour the water first because it takes you a few seconds to get up and into the kitchen and, adding the time it takes to get the milk, pour it then put it back, the water will have sat for a bit and won't be steaming hot anymore. Idk, though, it might just be my family's way of doing it.
